newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian navy evacuates foreign hostages on barge.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian navy evacuates foreign hostages on barge.

text.p: All 28 hostages held on an offshore barge by Nigerian workers demanding big pay rises have been released unharmed, a Philippine diplomat said on Saturday.
The hostages, who were held for five days before being released on Friday, were all foreigners - 10 Filipinos, nine Frenchmen, five Indians, two Britons, one Lebanese and one Belgian.
"They are safe now. They were taken off the barge yesterday by the navy and brought to the naval base in Calabar," Hermes Dorado, consul-general of the Philippine embassy in Lagos, told Reuters.
They had been held hostage on the barge about 30 miles offshore from the oil-producing town of Eket since December 23 by 60 Nigerian workers.
Dorado said the Nigerians had also been evacuated by the navy to its base but he did not know the outcome of negotiations launched earlier to end the siege.
"I don't know what the Nigerian authorities or the employers of the workers will do. My main concern is that the people have been taken off the barge and are safe," he said.
The dispute involved a French oil services company identified as NTPM that employed the workers on its barge, the WB-82, which transports crude oil from onshore fields to tankers.
The Nigerians had not been armed and had not carried out a threat to act against the foreigners if their demands were not met by Thursday.
Mobil Nigeria Unlimited, a joint venture with the U.S. firm Mobil Corp, is the main producer of crude oil in that area. A Mobil official said the company was not involved in the incident.
